## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 103, 675, 529]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space, \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space, \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space, \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) elementary charge, \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant, \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass constant, \(u = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron, \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton, \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant, \(R = 8.31\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant, \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant, \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant, \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall, \(g = 9.81\mathrm{m s}^{- 2}\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 106, 556, 141]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]

\[W = \rho \Delta V\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 191, 532, 220]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 256, 571, 287]]<|/det|>

\[V = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_0r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[426, 428, 621, 448]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 466, 591, 485]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 500, 522, 522]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 536, 591, 555]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[426, 572, 621, 591]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 606, 556, 625]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 642, 576, 661]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 675, 532, 710]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[453, 58, 544, 78]]<|/det|>
**Section A**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[298, 102, 700, 122]]<|/det|>
Answer **all** the questions in the spaces provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 149, 96, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 149, 144, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 430, 168]]<|/det|>
State Newton's law of gravitation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 272, 146, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 272, 801, 291]]<|/det|>
A satellite of mass \(m\) is in a circular orbit of radius \(r\) about a planet of mass \(M.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 286, 875, 322]]<|/det|>
For this planet, the product \(G M\) is \(4.00 \times 10^{14} \text{N} \text{m}^{2} \text{kg}^{-1}\), where \(G\) is the gravitational constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 319, 586, 339]]<|/det|>
The planet may be assumed to be isolated in space.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 350, 180, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 350, 873, 384]]<|/det|>
By considering the gravitational force on the satellite and the centripetal force, show that the kinetic energy \(E_{\mathrm{K}}\) of the satellite is given by the expression

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 390, 551, 420]]<|/det|>
\[E_{\mathrm{K}} = \frac{GMm}{2r}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 581, 875, 600]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 612, 181, 631]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 612, 875, 645]]<|/det|>
The satellite has mass \(620\mathrm{kg}\) and is initially in a circular orbit of radius \(7.34\times 10^{6}\mathrm{m}\), as illustrated in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 875, 108]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 118, 183, 137]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 118, 520, 137]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 241, 181, 260]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 241, 875, 275]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 855, 92]]<|/det|>
